_prev_prog_3.Description: Unit 3 is a dual reactor fluid catalytic cracker (FCC) designed to charge 10% resid from Unit 9 and 90% hydrotreated gas oil from Unit 26.1.
Unit 4 is a gas plant divided into two parts:  the catalytic cracker gas plant where FCC gases are processed, and the east end towers that process streams from the various units within the facility.
Unit 5 consists of drying facilities for butanes/butylenes, propane/propylene, and  isobutane.  In addition, Unit 5 treats the total alkylate from Unit 30.
Unit 6 South Section processes butanes/butylenes from Unit 8 LPG, Unit 27 FCC and the Coker unit, converting the butadiene to butane and isomerizing 1-butene to 2-butene.

Unit 8 is designed to remove the sulfur contaminants from the Coker unit propane/propylene streams and the Unit 4 butane/butylene streams.  In addition, Unit 8 can charge off-test propylene from the CPCC ethylene units or ouitside p/p.
Unit 9 is a crude unit designed to process low sulfur crude and to separate the crude into various fractions for further processing into finished products.

Unit 11 High End Point (HEP) Naptha Hydrotreaters consists of two sections: the hydrodesulfurizing section and the gas treating section.  The purpose of the unit is to reduce the sulfur content of naptha before being processed in Unit 35.
Unit 14 Low End Point (LEP) Naptha Hydrotreater is a hydrodesulfurizing (HDS) unit that takes the raw naptha feed and removes sulfur and nitrogen compounds before being processed in Unit 35.
Unit 15 is a hexane processing unit that produces motor fuel and normal hexane solvent.
Unit 19 is a Benzene Hydrogenation unit that converts benzene to cyclohexane.
Unit 20 is a Pentane Isomerization unit that converts normal pentane to isopentane.

Unit 25.1 Crude Desalter and Fractionator Unit is a crude unit revamped to process Merey crude.   Its purpose is to separate the crude into various fractions and remove salts, solids, free water and sulfur compounds for further processing into finished products.

Unit 25.2 is a Hydrodesulfurization (HDS) unit designed to process distillate.  Its purpose is to remove enough sulfur from the feed to meet environmental specifications on products and to separate the feed into kerosene and diesel for sale.

Unit 26.1 is an Atmospheric Residuum Desulfurization (ARDS) unit modified to process gas oils from Unit  25.1 Sour Crude unit, Unit 29.1 Vacuum Distillation unit, Unit 29.2 Delayed Coker unit and naptha from Unit 29.2.
Unit 26.2 is a Hydrogen Purification unit designed to process light gases.  Its purpose is to separate the gases into various products for use in other units.
Unit 27 is designed to convert feedstock into lighter, more valuable products such as: propylene, butylenes, gasoline and light cycle oil.

Unit 29.2 Delayed Coker unit processes vacuum residuum feed from Unit 29.1 and feed from Sour Crude Unit 25.1.  Unit 29.2 is also able to process refinery slop oils.   Light coker gas oils and heavy coker gas oils are fed to the ARDS Unit 26.1.
Unit 30 is a Hydrofluoric Acid (HF) unit designed to produce Alkylate product from Cat Cracker and Coker unit butane/butylene and propane/propylene streams.

_prev_prog_3.CT_OtherType: Revisions to Certification Tests to Administer
_prev_prog_3.Description: The Unit 35 Continuous Catalyst Regeneration (CCR) Reformer is designed to process hydrotreated naptha from Units 11 and 14 and convert it into high octane, high aromatic products.
Unit 52 is the raw water treatment system designed to produce cooling tower makeup water and boiler makeup feedwater.

The Refinery Tank Farm (RTF) serves as a storage facility for the complex.  The RTF serves mainly as an intermediate storage facility for the processing units as well as for the intermediate storage of finished products.
The Sweeny Tank Farm (STF) serves as a product storage facility for the complex.
Unit 87 is the facility's Tank Car Loading Rack for loading and unloading of products and feedstocks used throughout the complex.

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Environmental impact; equipment damage; business interruption.
_prev_prog_3.Description: Unit 250.513 Residue Gas Compressors: The overall Fuel Gas System supplies the Cogeneration Plant's combustion turbines and duct burners in order to meet the steam production demands of the facility. A combination of two types of gases are used, residue gas and natural gas. Residue gas is derived as a by-product from the distillation process at the Refinery, and natural gas is supplied to the Cogeneration plant from an outside source. The residue gas compressors discharge to a common header which supplies the fuel blending skids at the Cogeneration Plant.

_prev_prog_3.Description: Unit 38 Diesel Hydrotreater (Note: this unit/process involves predictive filing; Unit is expected to startup in 2006). The Ultra Low Sulfur Diesel Hydrotreater processes 70,000 BPSD of a mixture predominantly of straight run diesel and cycle oils and includes about 17% of Coker naphtha. The process removes sulfur from the feed by converting it, in the presence of a cobalt-molybdenum catalyst, to hydrogen sulfide in the presence of excess hydrogen. The liquid is separated from the treat gas and stripped to remove hydrogen sulfide and light ends. The resulting ultra-low sulfur diesel product is run down to final product storage tanks.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN - CORRECTION (2005)

CONOCOPHILLIPS COMPANY 

SWEENY REFINERY 

I.  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

Sweeny Refinery has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training, written procedures, routine maintenance and inspection programs, and consideration of safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes. Our policy is to implement controls to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous chemicals. However, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.


II.  DESCRIPTION OF THE FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Sweeny Refinery consists of four major facilities, which are linked by multiple pipelines and operates as a single unit. The main plant, near Old Ocean, Texas, is at the intersection of State Highway 35 and FM 524, about 60 miles southwest of downtown Houston. We also operate terminals and storage facilities in Freeport, Jones Creek, and San Bernard, along with the pipelines that connect these facilities to the main plant and its markets. The refinery covers approximately 3,000 acres at the four locations, the plant processes 213,000 barrels per day of crude oil and produces 115,000 barrels per day of gasoline. In our process, we use the following chemicals that EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant, offsite consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release:

Toxics:  HF Acid, Chlorine, Ammonia-anhydrous 

Flammables: 1-Butene; 1-3-Butadiene; 2-Butene; 2-Butene-trans; 2-Butene-cis; 2-Pentene; 2-2-Dimethylpropane; 3-Methyl-1-Butene; Acetylene (ethyne); Butene; Ethane; Ethylene; Hydrogen; Isobutane; Isopentane; Isoprene; Methane; Normal Butane; Pentane; Propadiene; Propane; Propylene; Vinyl Acetylene (1-Buten-3-yne); 


III.  HAZARD ASSESSMENT RESULTS

At the heart of the Risk Mana

gement Plan rule is the requirement to conduct a hazard assessment to examine and communicate potential offsite effects of releases of regulated hazardous substances.  Two types of releases are to be considered, a Worst Case Scenario and an Alternate Release Scenario.  The WCS (representing a catastrophic event) is defined as a release with the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a single vessel or process line failure and that results in the greatest distance to a specified endpoint.  The ARS represents a more credible, but still significant, accidental release of regulated hazardous material. It is also understood that active and passive mitigation systems can be considered in developing the ARS.  However, in some cases mitigation measures and systems may have not been included to its fullest extent in order to create potential worst-case alternate release scenarios.  In helping to establish the Alternate Release Scenarios that are more credible and likely, various information such as previous incident history, PHA failure scenarios, siting and spacing studies, etc. was considered. 
 

Note:  For Security purposes, the Offsite Consequence Analysis description and scenarios has been removed from Executive Summary.


IV.  GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS

The following is a summary of the general Accident Prevention Program in place at the Sweeny Refinery. Because processes at the plant are subject to both EPA RMP and  OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) compliance, this summary addresses each of the PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the Accident Prevention Program.

A.  Employee Participation

Sweeny Refinery management encourages employees to participate in all facets of risk management and accident prevention. Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information to participating as a member of a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) team. Emplo

yees have access to all information created as part of the Sweeny Refinery's Accident Prevention Program. In addition, Sweeny Refinery has a number of initiatives under way that address process safety and employee safety issues. These initiatives include forming teams to promote both process safety and employee safety. The teams typically have members from various areas of the plant, including operations, maintenance, engineering and plant management.

Personnel representing operations, maintenance, office, and management work together on the Employee Excellence Team to represent the employees and address the following elements of the facility Operating Excellence Plan:

* Behavior Awareness (Employee Behavioral Safety Process (VIPER), Safety in Motion - ergonomics)
* Employee Ownership (traffic safety, general safety, safety concerns, and tracking system)
* Waste Minimization (recycle program, waste prevention and minimization)
* Safety Standards and Procedures (review, edit, create, and Performed-Based Self Audits)

B.  Process Safety Information

Sweeny Refinery keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to maintain safe operation of the processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information.   Specific departments within the complex are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date Process Safety Information. Process Safety Information reference documents are readily available as. Part of .the written Employee Participation Plan to help employees locate any necessary Process Safety Information.

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs). For specific process areas, the complex has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, level, and compos

ition) in the unit-specific Process Safety Information (PSI) document. The teams verify the process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel and protective instrument systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems).

Sweeny Refinery also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to confirm that safety features in the process are not compromised.

C.  Process Hazard Analysis

Sweeny Refinery has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled: Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and verify that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.

Sweeny Refinery primarily uses the HAZard and Operability (HAZOP) analysis technique to perform these evaluations. HAZOP analysis is recognized as one of the most systematic and thorough hazard evaluation techniques. The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise. This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.

The PHA Team findings are identified and forwarded to the respective team management for resolution. Implementation of mitigation options in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team. This ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive im

mediate attention. All approved mitigation options being implemented in response to PHA team findings are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.

To confirm the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate significantly from the original design safety features, Sweeny Refinery periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating. The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained. Once again, the team findings are forwarded to management for consideration, and the final resolution of the findings is documented and retained.

D.  Operating Procedures

Sweeny Refinery maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) unit startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) initial startup of a new process. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. These procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate. The procedures are maintained current and accurate by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made through the Management of Change process.

In addition, Sweeny Refinery maintains a Process Safety Information document that provides guidance on how to respond to upper or lower limit exceedances for specific process or equipment parameters. This information, along with written operating procedures, is readily available to operators in the process unit and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job tasks.

E.  Training

To complement the written procedures for process operations, Sweeny Refinery has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved i

n operating a process. New employees receive basic training in plant operations if they are not already familiar with such operations. After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks. After operators demonstrate (e.g., through tests, skills demonstration) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to confirm their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. All of this training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training.

F.  Contractors

Sweeny Refinery uses contractors as part of its regular work force during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the plant has procedures in place to verify contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform plant personnel of any hazards that they find during their work. This is accomplished, by providing contractors with (1) a Process Overview, (2) information about safety and health hazards, (3) Emergency Response Plan requirements, and (4) safe work practices prior to their beginning work. In addition, Sweeny Refinery evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the selection of a contractor. Plant personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to help ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations. Contractors regularly participate in facility emergency drills.

G.  Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSR)

Sweeny Refinery conducts a PSSR for any new facility or

facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to confirm safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service. This review provides one additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. The PSSR review team uses checklists to verify all aspects of readiness. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that Accident Prevention Program requirements are properly implemented.

H.  Mechanical Integrity

Sweeny Refinery has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.

Maintenance personnel receive training on (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) Emergency Response Plans, and (5) applicable safe work practices to help ensure they can perform their job in a safe manner. Written procedures confirm work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training. Inspections and tests are performed to verify equipment functions as intended, and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels). If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service (if possible), or an MOC

cilities (see Unit 68)

Sweeny Refinery Complex has a longstanding commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training, written procedures, routine maintenance and inspection programs,  and consideration of safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes. However, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.

Sweeny Refinery Complex consistconsists of five four major facilities, which are linked by multiple pipelines and operates as a single unit. The main plant, near Old Ocean, Texas, is at the intersection of State Highway 35 and FM 524, about 60 miles southwest of downtown Houston. We also operate terminals and storage facilities in Freeport, Jones Creek, and San Bernard, along with the pipelines that connect these facilities to the main plant and its markets. lly monitor contractor performance to help ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations. Contractors regularly participate in facility emergency drills.





G.  Prestartup Safety Reviews (PSSR)



Sweeny RefineryComplex conducts a PSSR for any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to confirm safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service. This review provides one additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. The PSSR review team uses checklists to verify all aspects of readiness. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that Accident Prevention Program requirements are properly implemented.





H.  Mechanical Integrity



Sweeny RefineryComplex has wellestablished practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, 

piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency 

shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) 

conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) 

correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures. In combination, 

these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.



Maintenance personnel receive training on (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health 

hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) Emergency Response Plans, and (5) 

applicable safe work practices to help ensure they can perform their job in a safe manner. 

Written procedures confirm work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for

 training. Inspections and t

Team will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to verify the safe operation of the equipment.

Another integral part of the Mechanical Integrity Program is quality assurance. Sweeny Complex incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.

Sweeny Refinery has developed a team-based defect elimination process known as TPM (Team Perfected Manufacturing). The objective of this process is to eliminate equipment failures through predictive/ preventive maintenance and improve in operating reliability and safety.

I.  Safe Work Practices

Sweeny Refinery has long-standing safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety. Examples of these include (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, (2) a. Lockout/Tagout Procedure to verify isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (3) procedures for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened, (4) a permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities (i.e., hot work), (5) a permit and procedure to confirm adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space, and (6) a Safety and Emergency Systems Bypass Permit procedure.  These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

J.  Management of Change

Sweeny Refinery has a comprehensive system to manage change. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Changes are reviewed to (1) verify adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and (2) veri

fy existing controls have not been compromised by the change. Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training on the change.

K.  Incident Investigation

Sweeny Refinery promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the Root Cause and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to plant management and respective Teams for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years in order for reports to be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations.

L.  Compliance Audits.

To confirm the Accident Prevention Program is functioning properly, Sweeny Refinery periodically conducts audits to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the Accident Prevention Program are being implemented. Formal compliance audits are conducted at least every 2 years. In addition, Sweeny conducts internal self audits on a semiannual basis and annual evaluations on Sweeny's Operating Excellence Plan Process. Both hourly and management personnel participate as audit team members. The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to plant management for resolution. Corrective actions

taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.

M.  Sweeny Refinery Operating Excellence Plan

In addition, Sweeny Refinery utilizes a Health, Safety & Environmental Management process called Operating Excellence Plan.  This Plan helps drive continuous improvement in the HSE process and involve all employees of the facility.  This Plan is comprised of various HSE elements.  Action items or element enhancements for each element are identified and assigned to various groups/persons for action and response.  This Plan is reviewed and updated on an annual basis.  The elements of the Sweeny Refinery Operating Excellence Plan are:

* EMPLOYEE OWNERSHIP & AWARENESS
* TRAINING
* SAFETY & HEALTHI 
* COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT
* WASTE MINIMIZATION
* CONTRACTOR PERFORMANCE
* MONITORING & AUDITING
* NONCONFORMANCES, INVESTIGATION & CORRECTIVE ACTION
* STANDARDS & PROCEDURES
* ENGINEERING DESIGN
* POLLUTION PREVENTION
* MECHANICAL RELIABILITY
* RISK MANAGEMENT & EMERGENCY RESPONSE
* OPERATING INTEGRITY

* These elements, combined with the OSHA PSM elements, help ensure a comprehensive Accident Prevention Program.

N.  Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The processes at Sweeny Refinery have hazards that must be managed to help ensure continued safe operation. The Accident Prevention Program summarized previously is applied to all EPA RMP covered process at the plant. Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by (1) equipment failures and (2) human errors.

In addition to the Accident Prevention Program activities, Sweeny Refinery has safety features on many processes to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release. The following types of safety features are used in various processes:

Release Detection

* Gas

Detectors (Hydrocarbon, H2S, etc.) with Alarms

Release Containment/Control

* Process Relief Valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases
* Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automatic)
* Automated Shutdown Systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high level, high temperature, release detection)
* Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system, backup firewater  pump)
* Atmospheric Relief Devices
* Structural/Equipment Fire Proofing
* Relief valve maintenance procedures
* 
Release Mitigation

* Fire Suppression and Extinguishing Systems
* Deluge System for specific equipment
* Trained Emergency Response Personnel
* Personal Protective Equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)
* Control Building is located outside of potential release areas
* Water curtains for specific equipment
* Siting and Spacing Initiative
* Emergency Isolation Valves
* Emergency Activation System
* Risk Based Inspection


V.  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Over the past 5 years, there have been no RMP events with offsite impacts. There have been several on-site RMP-related incidents involving injuries and/or property damage as follows: 

* On 01/21/2000, there were injuries (no deaths) involving three maintenance employees due to an accidental release of a small amount of a covered toxic substance (HF acid) from process Unit 30.  Employees were involved in turnaround activities demolishing a section of line and while in the process of unbolting a flange, a liquid and vapor mixture containing HF acid leaked out and contacting the employees.  There was no property/equipment damage or offsite impact associated with this incident.

* On 01/08/2000, there was an injury (no death) involving a unit operator due to an accidental release of a small amount of a covered toxic substance (HF acid) from process unit 30.  Employee was in the process of preparing to rea

m out a 1" low point bleeder, when some HF acid dripped out of bleeder and contacting employee on forearm.  There was no property/equipment damage or offsite impact associated with this incident.

* On 06/18/2003, an incident involving a flammable mixture from an out-of-service storage tank from process Unit 68 Refinery Tank Farm (RTF), resulted in one contractor employee recordable-medical treatment injury and property damage. Contractor employee were in the process of gas-freeing the out-of-service storage tank for maintenance when a flash fire occurred. No offsite impact was associated with this incident. 

* On 06/07/2004, an incident involving a flammable mixture release and fire from process Unit 26.1 ARDS resulted in an employee recordable injury and property damage. Employees were in the process of isolating an exchanger for maintenance to repair a tube leak when the exchanger pressured up and released the flammable mixture through a vent line and igniting.

The Sweeny Refinery has a formal written incident investigation process that is designed to identify root causes of incidents and develop appropriate corrective actions to prevent recurrence.  Risk assessments are also made of incidents.  However, the Sweeny Refinery's focus and philosophy is in the area of preventing accidents, and controls and measures are developed and implemented to help accomplish this.


VI.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

Sweeny Refinery maintains a written Emergency Response Program, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency resp

onse agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. In addition, Sweeny Refinery has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. The Emergency Response Program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to plant processes or other plant facilities. 

The overall Emergency Response Program for Sweeny Refinery is coordinated with the Brazoria County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives. Sweeny Refinery has around-the-clock-communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire departments). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, Sweeny Refinery conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the LEPC and emergency response organizations. In addition to the LEPC, the Sweeny Refinery also has a Mutual Aid System in place. The Emergency Assistance Agreement Committee (EAAC) is a sub committee of the Industrial CAER organization in the Brazosport area. This system provides Mutual Aid from other industry members in the Brazosport area. In addition, the Brazoria Volunteer Fire Department and West Brazos Emergency Medical Services would provide assistance in the event of an emergency at the Sweeny Refinery. The EAAC conducts emergency drills quarterly each year, hosted by a facility with the other member facilities participating.


VII.  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

New and/or planned upcoming events or changes

to continue to improve safety at Sweeny Refinery include the following: 

* Additional Emergency Shutdown Valves on Critical Equipment Lines.
* Ongoing Facility Siting and Spacing Analysis and Reviews
* Dow Fire and Explosion Index Fire Water Curtain Analysis
* Area Process and Perimeter Detection Analysis
* Relief Valve and Relief Header Analysis
* State Implementation Plan - NOx Reduction Project
* Facility Security & Vulnerability Assessment
* Conducting Emergency & CAER Drills
* Relocation of Waste Water Discharge
* Review & Update Tank Fire Preplans
* Simulator Training Program for Operators

III.  HAZARD ASSESSMENT RESULTS



At the heart of the Risk Management Plan rule is the requirement to conduct a hazard assessment to examine and communicate potential offsite effects of releases of regulated hazardous substances.  Two types of releases are to be considered, a Worst Case Scenario and an Alternate Release Scenario.  The WCS (representing a catastrophic event) is defined as a release with the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a single vessel or process line failure and that results in the greatest distance to a specified endpoint.  The ARS represents a more credible, but still significant, accidental release of regulated hazardous material. It is also understood that active and passive mitigation systems can be considered in developing the ARS.  However, in some cases mitigation measures and systems may have not been included to its fullest extent in order to create potential worst-case alternate release scenarios.  In helping to establish the Alternate Release Scenarios that are more credible and likely, various information such as previous incident history, PHA failure scenarios, siting and spacing studies, etc. was considered. 

 



Note:  For Security purposes, the Offsite Consequence Analysis description and scenarios has

been removed from Executive Summary.



The worstcase scenario (WCS) associated with toxic substances is a catastrophic release of HF Acid (243,136 lbs) from the alkylation acid settler vessel. This maximum quantity was derived from an engineering review of the process. Although there are numerous controls to prevent such releases and to manage their consequences, no credit for either active or passive mitigation was taken into account in evaluating this scenario. The maximum distance to the toxic endpoint for HF Acid (0.016 mg/t) for this WCS is 14 miles (calculated using EPA?s RMPComp). This scenario has offsite impacts.



The alternatecase scenario (ACS) associated with toxic substances is a flange leak of HF Acid in the same process area listed for the WCS. Under the ACS, approximately 764 lbs of HF Acid released over a period of 10 minutes. Credit for active mitigation was taken into account in evaluating this scenario, including water spray/deluge systems, rapid acid transfer system, process and audible alarms/operator intervention, etc. The maximum distance to the toxic endpoint for BF Acid (0.016 mg/1) for this ACS is.3 miles (calculated using EPA's RMPComp). This scenario has offsite impacts.



The WCS associated with flammable substances is a vapor cloud explosion (VCE) involving 2,845,893 lbs of normal pentane from a storage tank in the Refinery Tank Farm. This WCS assumes the entire inventory of this vessel is released, vaporizes and ignites, resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. Although there are several controls to prevent such releases and to manage their consequences, no credit for mitigation was taken into account in evaluating this scenario. The maximum distance to the 1 psi1-psi endpoint for this WCS is 1.10 miles (calculated using EPA's RMPComp). This scenario has offsite impacts.



The ACS associated with flammable substances is a VCE involving a release of ethane whichethane, which may be caused by relieving light hydrocarbon liquids to

the atmosphere via a 6" x 8" pressure safety valve (PSV). The relief could result due to a pressure unequalization between the NGL sphere storage and the ethane rich feed from Unit 10.1. Additional, smaller PSVs could also relieve vapor and liquid to the flare header. 'The modeling was based upon a release of 300,000 lbs. of ethane. Credit for active mitigation was taken into account in evaluating this scenario including operator intervention and the smaller PSVs relieving to the flare header. The maximum distance to the 1 psi (or lower flammable level) endpoint for this ACS is 0.4 miles (calculated using EPA's RMPComp. This scenario has offsite impacts.





IV.  GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS



The following is a summary of the general Accident Prevention Program in place at the Sweeny Refinery Complex. Because processes at the plant are subject to both regulated by the EPA RMP and regulation are~also  subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) compliancestandard, this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the Accident Prevention Program.





A.  Employee Participation



Sweeny RefineryComplex management encourages employees to participate in all facets of risk management and accident prevention. Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information to participating as a member of a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) team. Employees have access to all information created as part of the Sweeny Refinery?sComplex's Accident Prevention Program. Specific ways that employees can be involved in the Accident Prevention Program are documented in the Employee Participation Element of the Sweeny Complex Risk Management System and in the Employee Participation Section of all other Risk Management Elements. In addition, Sweeny RefineryComplex has a number of initiatives under way that address process safety and employee sa

fety issues. These initiatives include forming teams to promote both process safety and employeepersonal safety. The teams typically have members from various areas of the plant, including operations, maintenance, engineering and plant management.



Personnel representing operations, maintenance, office, and management work together on the Employee Excellence Team Phillips Employee Excellence Team (PSEE) to represent the employees and address the following PSEE elements of the facility Operating Excellence Plan:Two key areas for employee  participation include the Employee Behavioral Safety Process (VIPER) and OSHA's Voluntary Protection Program. Sweeny Complex received the OSHA VPP Star as part of the inspection February, 1998 by OSHA.





* Behavior Awareness (Employee Behavioral Safety Process (VIPER), Safety in Motion ? ergonomics)

* Employee Ownership (traffic safety, general safety, safety concerns, and tracking system)

* Waste Minimization Pollution Prevention (recycle program, waste prevention and minimization)

* Safety Standards and Procedures (review, edit, create, and Performed-Based Self Audits)





B.  Process Safety Information



Sweeny RefineryComplex keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to maintain safe operation of the processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information.  :  Specific departments within the complex are assigned responsibility for  . maintaining uptodate Process Safety Information. Process Safety Information reference documents are readily available as. part of .the written Employee Participation Plan to help employees locate any necessary Process Safety Information.



Chemicalspecific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs). For specific process areas,

., the complex has documented safetyrelated limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, level, compositionand composition) in the unitspecific Process Safety Information (PSI) document. The teams verify the process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel and protective instrument systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems).



Sweeny RefineryComplex also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to confirm that safety features in the process are not compromised.





C.  Process Hazard Analysis



Sweeny RefineryComplex has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled: Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and verify that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.



Sweeny RefineryComplex primarily uses the HAZzard and OPerability (HAZOP) analysis technique to perform these evaluations. HAZOP analysis is recognized as one of the most systematic and thorough hazard evaluation techniques. The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise. This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.



The PHA Team findings are identified and forwarded to the respective team management local and corporate management for resolution. Implementation of mitigati

on options in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team. This ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive immediate attention. All approved mitigation options being implemented in response to PHA team findings are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.



To confirm the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate significantly from the original design safety features, Sweeny RefineryComplex periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating. The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained. Once again, the team findings are forwarded to management for consideration, and the final resolution of the findings is documented and retained.





D.  Operating Procedures



Sweeny RefineryComplex maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) unit startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) initial startup of a new process. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. These procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate. The procedures are maintained current and accurate by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made through the Management of Change process.



In addition, Sweeny RefineryComplex maintains a Process Safety Information document that provides guidance on how to respond to upper or lower limit exceedances for specific process or equipment parameters. This information, along with written operating procedures, is readily available to operators in the process unit and for other person

nel to use as necessary to safely perform their job tasks.







E.  Training



To complement the written procedures for process operations, Sweeny RefineryComplex has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process. New employees receive basic training in plant operations if they are not already familiar with such operations. After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn processspecific duties and tasks. After operators demonstrate (e.g., through tests, skills demonstration) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to confirm their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. All of this training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training.









F.  Contractors



Sweeny RefineryComplex uses contractors as part of its regular work force during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the plant has procedures in place to verify contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform plant personnel of any hazards that they find during their work. This is accomplished, by providing contractors with (1) a Process Overview, (2) information about safety and health hazards, (3) Emergency Response Plan requirements, and (4) safe work practices prior to their beginning work. In addition, Sweeny RefineryComplex evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the selection of a contractor. Plant personnel periodica

ests are performed to verify equipment functions as intended, and to 

verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure 

vessels). If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the 

equipment back into service (if possible), or an MOC Team will review the use of the equipment 

and determine what actions are necessary to verify the safe operation of the equipment.



Another integral part of the Mechanical Integrity Program is quality assurance. Sweeny Complex 

incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps ensure 

that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are 

used when repairs are made.



Sweeny RefineryComplex has developed a teambased defect elimination process known as TPM (Team 

Perfected Manufacturing). The objective of this employee driven process is to eliminate 

equipment failures through predictive/ and preventive maintenance and . As this process continues to

mature we expect continuous and substantial improvement in operating reliability and safety.





I.  Safe Work Practices



Sweeny RefineryComplex has longstanding safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and 

process safety. Examples of these include (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support 

personnel, (2) a. Lockout/Tagout Procedure to verify isolation of energy sources for equipment 

undergoing maintenance, (3) procedures for safe removal of hazardous materials before process 

piping or equipment is opened, (4) a permit and procedure to control sparkproducing activities 

(i.e., hot work), (5) a permit and procedure to confirm adequate precautions are in place before 

entry into a confined space, and (6) a Safety and Emergency Systems Bypass Permit procedure.  

These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help 

ensure that operations and m

aintenance activities are performed safely.





J.  Management of Change



Sweeny RefineryComplex has a comprehensive system to manage change. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Changes are reviewed to (1) verify adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and (2) verify existing controls have not been compromised by the change. Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training on the change.





K.  Incident Investigation



Sweeny RefineryComplex promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the Root Cause and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to plant management and respective Teams for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years in order for reports to be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations.





L.  Compliance Audits .Audits.



To confirm the Accident Prevention Program is functioning properly, Sweeny RefineryComplex periodically

conducts auditsan audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the Accident Prevention Program are being implemented. Formal cCompliance audits are conducted at at least every 23 years. In addition, Sweeny conducts (1) internal self audits on a semiannual basis and , (2) PSM Compliance audits on an annual basis, and (3)annual eva PSEE evaluations on Sweeny's Operating Excellence Plan Safety PProcess on an annual basis. Both hourly and management personnel participate as audit team members. The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to plant management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.

V.  FIVEYEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



Over the past 5 yearsyears, there have been no RMP events with offsite impactseffects. There have been several on-site RMP-related incidents involving injuries and/or property damage as follows:However, there were several accidental releases of regulated substances that involved onsite injuries as follows: 



* On 01/21/2000, there were injuries (no deaths) involving three maintenance employees due to an accidental release of a small amount of a covered toxic substance (HF acid) from process Unit 30.  Employees were involved in turnaround activities demolishing a section of line and while in the process of unbolting a flange, a liquid and vapor mixture containing HF acid leaked out and contacting the employees.  There was no property/equipment damage or offsite impact associated with this incident.



* OIn 01/08/2000, there was an injury (no death) involving a unit operator due to an accidental release of a small amount of a covered toxic substance (HF acid) from process unit 30.  Employee was in the process of preparing to ream out a 1? low point bleeder, when some HF acid dripped out of bleeder and contacting employee on forearm.  There was no property/equipment damage or offsite impact associated with this incident.



* On 06/18/2003, an incident involving a flammable mixture from an out-of-service storage tank from process Unit 68 Refinery Tank Farm (RTF), resulted in one contractor employee reco

rdable-medical treatment injury and property damage.  Contractor employees were in the process of gas-freeing the out-of-service storage tank for maintenance when a flash fire occurred.  No offsite impact was associated with this incident.



* On 06/07/2004, an incident involving a flammable mixture release and fire from process Unit 26.1 ARDS resulted in an employee recordable injury and property damage.  Employees were in the process of isolating an exchanger for maintenance to repair a tube leak when the exchanger pressured up and released the flammable mixture through a vent line and igniting.     



The Sweeny Refinery has a formal written incident investigation process that is designed to identify root causes of incidents and develop appropriate corrective actions to prevent recurrence.  Risk assessments are also made of incidents.  However, the Sweeny Refinery?s focus and philosophy is in the area of preventing accidents, and controls and measures are developed and implemented to help accomplish this.







Every incident is carefully investigated to determine ways to prevent similar incidents from occurring.

VI.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION



Sweeny RefineryComplex maintains a written Emergency Response Program, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper firstaid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and postincident cleanup and decontamination requirements. In addition, Sweeny RefineryComplex has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as w

ell as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. The Emergency Response Program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to plant processes or other plant facilities. The Emergency Response Program changes are administered through the MOC process, which includes informing and/or training affected personnel in the changes.



The overall Emergency Response Program for Sweeny RefineryComplex is coordinated with the Brazoria County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives. Sweeny RefineryComplex has aroundtheclockcommunications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire departments). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, Sweeny RefineryComplex conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the LEPC and emergency response organizations. In addition to the LEPC, the Sweeny RefineryComplex also has a Mutual Aid System in place. The Emergency Assistance Agreement Committee (EAAC) is a sub committee of the Industrial CAER organization in the Brazosport area. This system provides Mutual Aid from other industry members in the Brazosport area. In addition, the Brazoria Volunteer Fire Department and West Brazos Emergency Medical Services would provide assistance in the event of an emergency at the Sweeny RefineryComplex. The EAAC conducts emergency drills quarterly each year, hosted by a facility with the other member facilities participating.





VII.  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



New and/or planned upcoming events or changes to continue to improve safety at Sweeny Ref

inery include the following: Sweeny Complex Terminal resolves all findings from PHA's, some of which result in modifications to the process. The following types of changes are planned:



* ? Additional Emergency Shutdown Valves on Ccritical Eequipment Llines.



* ? Ongoing Facility Siting and Spacing Analysis and Reviews



* ? Dow Fire and Explosion Index Fire Water Curtain Analysis





* ? Area Process and Perimeter Detection Analysis



* ? Relief Valve and Relief Header Analysis





* ? State Implementation Plan - IP NOx Reduction Project

* Facility Security & Vulnerability Assessment

* Conducting Emergency & CAER Drills

* Relocation of Waste Water Discharge

* Review & Update Tank Fire Preplans

* Simulator Training Program for Operators
